abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts substantial, while both
            the Bank, and Borrower performances are rated highly
            satisfactory. The success of the project lies mostly, on
            that the health reforms, however complex, addressed both the
            imminent financing, and delivery of health services, which
            simplistic solutions alone, only addressing one element of
            the health sector could not have accomplished. Lessons
            contributing to the success of the project feature a strong
            government commitment, institutional capacity and high
            technical skills (namely, a strong technical committee able
            to negotiate with key players in the health system), and, a
            well coordinated technical assistance, supported by timely
            Bank interventions, with attention to institutional
            development in the context of health reforms. However,
            regardless of success, lessons address weaknesses and
            challenges. Health outcomes were poorly defined, unclear for
            planning a baseline, and follow-up survey, including limited
            data to cross-validate findings, conducive to an ill-defined
            project evaluation which would have allowed determining
            impacts in terms of intermediate health indicators, and
            outcomes. Nonetheless, identification of this issue during
            implementation, allowed for stronger monitoring and
            evaluation criteria in the follow-up operation. In addition,
            allocation of counterpart funds was affected due to the
            economic crisis in Russia, and budget management problems.
